div.p:
A brief Memoir of
Mary Elizabeth Maud who departed this life March 8th. 1853. ---

When I review my mispent days, I feel a heavy burden, Reflecting on my trespasses, I scarce could hope for pardon, But should be hopeless and forlorn, Uncertain where for help to turn. If I had not thy promise. But thy reviving Gospel word which leads me to salvation Doth joy unspeakable afford. And lasting consolation: This tells me thou wilt not disdain A broken heart reflects with pain, That turns to

thee, O Jesus. This is the language of my heart, when about to call to mind the mercies which the Lord has vouchsafed unto me. I was born in London 1764, and baptized in the Established Church. When young I attended the meetings in the Brethren's Chapel and received powerful impressions of our Saviour's love. My dear Mother's anxious care for my spiritual welfare, her good advice and prayers, proved even in my

childhood a blessing: and in after periods of my life, were a check to me, and through mercy, the means of preserving me from many troubles. In April 1781, I went to live in the Srs House in Fulneck, and was at that time really intent upon living to our Saviour alone. - I soon felt at home, loved my companions and was very happy: but found that I had much to learn of the depravity of my heart - I was much [?] at this discovery, But most

earnestly prayed our Saviour to have mercy upon me, and if it was his will, to take me to himself, rather than suffer me to prove unfaithful. He kindly heard & [?] [?] me though not in my way. I laboured to gain a particular clearness of the forgiveness of my sins, which our Saviour did not grant me all at one :| but yet I knew he died for me, & could not think he would suffer me a poor sinner to be lost, while crying to him for mercy -.My

constant thought was - "If I do perish, it shall be at the foot of the cross." On the 5th of Novr. of the same year, I had the favour to be received into the Congregation which raised my drooping spirits, & increased my confidence in my faithful Saviour:I began to think I was owned by him, and solemnly promised, through His enabling grace to remain faithful until death. In September 1782, I was permitted to partake of the Holy Comn. with the Congn for the first time

which proved a real blessing to me, & for some time I remained in a cheerful frame of mind. In May 1782, I was received into the Sr's choir. In June 1786, I removed to the School, relying entirely upon our Saviour for his support & grace to fulfill my duties during the nine years I spent ​​​​​​in that house, I enjoyed many blessings in fellowship with the dear children, but had to experience many trials & difficulties known only to God. In the year 1795 I went

to reside in London, & take charge of my dear Mother, whose age & encreasing increasing infirmities required my assistance. This change of circumstances was at the time, a severe trial to me - but it proved good for my soul. I had to struggle with many difficulties, one of which was bad health; but tho' a sharp School, a blessed one, for it taught me to depend wholly on my Heavenly Father - who suffered not my con- fidence to be put to shame. In 1804 my dear Mother

departed this life happily, and her frequent prayers that the Lord would bless me for my attentions to her, have certainly been fulfulled; Though for some years subsequent to her death, my course was dark & gloomy, yet my faith in God was unshaken. In 1813, I was married to Mr. Samuel John Maud, entering that important state with prayer, and full reliance on our Saviour's help in every trial - which indeed I experienced. In 1824, He departed this

life happily, tho' from the nature of his complaint, he was seldom able to express his sentiments. Thus I entered a new state, while new & unforseen difficulties crowd- ed upon me, & had I not known my Saviour, what should I have done. In 1827 I recd. a call to Bristol, to be choir labourer of the widows; instead of taking it simply out of the Lord's hand, I yielded to reason only, and could not feel freedom to accept it: by degrees however I found I was wrong, knew that

our Saviour demanded it of me, and therefore had to humble myself before the Lord, and entreat his pardon, but my reasoning at time, has often caused me sorrow & regret. Since that period, the Lord has been seen good to visit me with many trials, some quite unexpected, that in my weak state, I feel rather hard to bear - yet am sure all has been for my good, and that whatever comes from his dear hand, how hard it be, how strange soever - I'll take it with a
passive heart, And tho' I cannot shout for gladness, But keenly feel afflictions dart yet I would not be sunk in sadness. -

Our late Sister was in the habit of keeping a kind of journal for many years. and some extracts from it will tend to shew show the intimate communion in which she lived with her Saviour - On the 16th. of January she wrote as follows (1831). When I reflect on the mercies bestowed on me this day, I feel bow'd down with

gratitude to a merciful Saviour that he has given that portion of health to enable me to attend the means of grace - each opportunity was blest blessed to me in a most striking manner - I do most firmly believe that our Saviour will cause this trying period to prove in the end a wholesome affliction; O may we all be purified & made meek for Eternity, and may grace be still continued to those who are appointed to minister to us.- January 1st. 1835. -
Entered this year with peculiar feelings at my advanc'd

age, it is mow now likely to be my last, than that I should cumber the ground longer, but whether I reach the end or not, I feel resigned, and only pray the Lord to forgive my sins, & take me to himself in mercy, where I hope to find real rest. Augst. 13th This morning was in spirit with our Congns who celebrate this memorial day, my mind was carried back 53 years, when I had the favour to be spectator at the Comn the last time, & can truly say mercy & goodness have fol-

lowed me all my life. and now I am favoured to reside near the house of God, I hope till my departure out of this world vale of tears, at present it is one to me, no doubt to purify me, and make me more fit for Eternal rest. Novr. 4th. What shall I say of the Lords mercies [?] [?] years, I am bow'd down to the dust with gratitude, & humbly devote myself to him, soul & body, I felt my deficiances deficiencies deeply, but have confidence that my gracious Saviour will not forsake me in my old age.
